headline: Horton Grove Stable, Durham vicinity, Durham County, North Carolina, 3500 Hall Road, Durham County, North Carolina UTM: 36.127786; -78.838790
description: Large tripartite frame barn with board and batten siding, queen post truss, surviving feed boxes, central longitudinal aisle. Built about 1860. Pul Cameron, wrote his father-in-law, Thomas Ruffin, in Sept. 1860: 'I have a great wish to show you the 'best stables' ever built in Orange [County] 135 feet long covered with cypress shingles at a cost of $6 per thousand.' Queen post trusses of main block
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Hyde Park Slave Quarter, 6808 West Courthouse Road, Burkeville, Nottoway County, Virginia
description: National Register Nomination for Hyde Park suggests the house was likely built between 1762 and 1782 by John Fowlkes. This includes the central portion of the house built with English bond cellar walls and Flemish above. The house was significantly rebuilt and retrimmed around 1840 possibly by Paschal J. Fowlkes. It was purchased in 1938 by Richmond department store owner William B. Thalhimer who used it as a training farm for Jewish students from Nazi Germany of the German agricultural Gross Breesen Institute. Two buildings sat to the rear of the house. One recently collapsed, leaving standing its two brick end chimneys. The Thalhimers referred to that building as the overseers' house, although it likely served as a kitchen and service building, with quarters upstairs--possibly for the overseer. A second structure remains standing that likely served as a double slave quarter. It is of frame construction and consists two rooms with a center chimney. Each room has its own, front exterior door. A tight winder stair rose in the front corner of the right room to an unheated and unfinished attic accessed only from the one side. The interior of the quarter appears to have had no finish until the 20th century. The frame sits on stone piers. The chimney is constructed of stone and includes large cooking fireplaces in each room. They are each spanned by a large oak lintel beveled on its rear and a wooden trammel bar that ran the width of the fireplace, set into its flue. Built of hewn and pit sawn framing and with mature, machine-cut nails. Conceivably it was constructed around 1840 when the house was first improved. The structure has been assumed to have been constructed as the kitchen and laundry for the site, but that seems unlikely.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: Talheimer,Hyde Park,quarter,slave quarter,slave,enslaved,work,double quarter,slave house,timber frame,center chimney

headline: Cloverfields, Foreman Landing Road, Queen Anne's County, Maryland
description: Built by Philemon Hemsley in 1704-05. William Hemsley improved the property in 1727-28 shortlybefore he patented the land in 1730. Brick, hall/parlor palan, two stories, with rear stair tower. Bent principal rafter roof. Clapboard cockloft. Clapboard roof sheathing. Foliated H hinges in attic. Attic flooring tulip poplar. In the late 1760s made into a double-pile, center-passage plan house. Eleaborate new woodwork, including plaster paneling, wood raised paneling, rococo consoles on sides of mantel, carved fretwork in the Chinese style in mantels, large scale moldings
creator: Willie Graham

headline: Robert E. Lee Monument, Monument Avenue, Richmond, Virginia
description: BLM reinterpretation of the Robert E. Lee Monument, May 6, 2020. 'Black Lives Matter' and portrait of George Floyd and other African Americans killed by police brutality, projected by Dustin Klein (videometryvisuals@gmail.com; 910.409.9062) onto the Robert E. Lee Monument. Cornerstone for the monument laid on October 27, 1887. Bronze statue by French sculptor Antonin Mercié. It was dedicated May 29, 1890.
creator: Willie Graham
categories: BLM,Black Lives Matter,George Floyd,Robert E Lee,memorial,Robert E Lee Monument,statue,Civil War
